name: 國際經濟
comment: Students must have enough exposure to economics - 2 years of economics learning on any subject is the basic requirement - according to a top tier north American liberal arts college.
description:
This course is divided into two parts. Part 1 is labeled “International Trade” and examines static models of trade (intra-temporal trade) while Part 2 is labeled “International Macroeconomics” and examines dynamic models of trade (inter-temporal trade) and monetary issues. 

The primary objectives of Part 1 of this course are to rigorously examine economic models and empirical studies of international trade. This part of the course is primarily organized to present the evolution of thought in the branch of international economics which focuses on intra-temporal trade in goods and services. We will examine theories that offer explanations for why countries trade, that present various determinants of the pattern of trade, and that examine the positive and normative effects of trade.

The primary objectives of Part 2 of this course are to examine issues associated with intertemporal trade using balance of payments analysis, the behavior of nominal and real exchange rates, and relationships among countries’ business cycles.
goals: To introduce the basic analytical tools to evaluate the economic issues associated with the interaction of a country with the international markets.
Provide the analytical framework to understand the role that firms play in a country’s economic performance, such as productivity, current account balance and growth
Provide rigorous treatment for how firms access international market through investment in customers and technology, and how these decisions affect the home and destination countries
syllabus:
1\. Introduction to international trade

2 – 4. Classical models of International Trade

5 Empirical Tests of Trade Patterns

6\. Trade Policy with perfect competition

7\. Trade with Imperfect Competition

8\. Gravity Models: Who trade with whom and the importance of geographic distance

9\. Midterm

10 - 12. Firms in international trade

13\. Introduction to international macroeconomics

14\. National and International Accounts and Transactions

15 - 17. Nominal and real exchange rates and monetary policy in an open economy

18\. Final
